Award.AwardTitle: Conference: Large-Scale Land-Use Transformations: Implications for Social-Ecological Systems and Resilience

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project brings together researchers from various disciplines working on linked ecological and social change to examine the effects of large-scale land-use change associated with developments such as plantation agriculture and the construction of dams on environmental and socio-economic sustainability. The project will focus on the Omo-Turkana Basin and support a workshop allowing local and international researchers to share experiences and synthesize existing knowledge about developments in the region using a social-ecological resilience framework. The workshop will open up opportunities for future multi-disciplinary research by supporting the formation of an umbrella organization for ongoing research in the region, strengthening linkages between researchers, and allowing members to develop collaborative research agendas. International students and early career researchers are also well represented, enhancing the network's capacity for future growth. A wider outcome of the workshop and network will be to inform decision-makers in the region of the results of on-going research, contributing scientifically robust evidence to better inform debate among policymakers and the public. In addition to a multi-disciplinary, landscape-scale situation analysis, the workshop will generate a series of policy briefs to facilitate the dissemination of outputs to non-academic audiences.

The project engages the concept of resilience and will use the workshop to advance the idea of resilience assessment. An objective of the workshop and research network will be to ascertain whether the large-scale land-use change occurring in the Omo-Turkana region supports the economic and social goals declared by project planners, or whether economic growth is being prioritized over the quality and resilience of environmental and social systems. Given the landscape-wide impact of development in the Omo-Turkana Basin, a theoretical basis is required that integrates contributions from multiple disciplines and therefore represents all elements of a social-ecological system. Resilience is one such theory, and this project will contribute to the literature by using the strong representation of social and political sciences in the network to better address equity and power relations within a resilience framing. Such a framing has generalizable relevance for other contexts, and as such, should be useful to science and society well beyond the specific case at hand.

POR.DRECONTENT:
“Workshop: Large-Scale Land-Use Transformations: Implications for Social-Ecological Systems and Resilience” brought together seventeen researchers to create a multi-disciplinary situation analysis of development in the Omo-Turkana Basin (Ethiopia and Kenya). On the Ethiopian side of the Basin, construction of the tallest hydroelectric dam in Africa has transformed the flood regime of the Omo River and been coupled with the construction of a large sugarcane estate. The combination will reduce the input to Lake Turkana in Kenya, disrupting a social-ecological system that currently supports 0.5 million people through herding, farming, and fishing.

The NSF funding through this grant supported a workshop in Nairobi, Kenya in 2016 and further travel for three of the participants to visit Ethiopia to meet with potential partners and disseminate our workshop findings in 2017. The workshop allowed Ethiopian, Kenyan, and international researchers to share their experiences and data and had four goals:

  1. Establish the background of the participants and their research interests, and providing time for building networks and trust between the participants.
  2. Establish the current status of the Omo-Turkana developments from a multi-disciplinary perspective.
  3. Identifying topics and authors for both a situation analysis and series of briefing notes.
  4. Brainstorming multi-disciplinary research ideas and designing a common research agenda.

The main product of the workshop was a journal article ‘Social-Ecological Change in the Turkana Basin: A Synthesis of Current Developments’, which synthesizes all the participants’ knowledge about the impacts ongoing within the region, using a social-ecological resilience framework. The workshop opened up opportunities for future multi-disciplinary research by supporting the formation of an umbrella organization (the Omo-Turkana Research Network (OTuRN)) for ongoing research in the region, strengthening linkages between researchers, creating a common identity, and allowing affiliates to develop collaborative research agendas. OTuRN now has over 50 affiliates, of whom 41% are early career researchers – strengthening the network’s capacity for future growth and productivity. Affiliates have been productive in the last year, in addition to completing the journal article they have organized two sessions at international conferences and submitted eight interdisciplinary research proposals, of which four were funded.

A wider outcome of the workshop and network was to inform decision-makers in the region of the results of on-going academic research, contributing scientifically robust evidence to better inform debate among policymakers and the Kenyan and Ethiopian publics. To facilitate the dissemination of outputs to non-academic audiences, the workshop participants also generated a series of policy briefs, freely available on the OTuRN website and covering topics such as the Kuraz Sugar Development Project, Lake Turkana and its fishing livelihoods, villigization in the Lower Omo, and the historical context of Lake Turkana. The 2017 travel allowed us to meet with other potential OTuRN affiliates in Ethiopia, and to distribute the first briefing note to a range of academic, governmental, and non-governmental institutions.
